You don't go wasting all your horses and dragoons on a charge that might end with them getting routed by a cannonade. A coordinated cavalry charge was only to be used in very specific circumstances in the age of muskets, since even an unbroken line of infantry had a pretty good chance of shitting on your fancy horses. Same principle as a phalanx, the horses aren't going to want to run right through a wall of pointy sticks no matter how you goad them.
>have some men fuck their flanks from the brush
You assume too much about their positioning and the scope of the battle. For all we know, beyond that brush is a flank skirmish. Armies weren't stupid at that time, they had scouts and lines of communication that would call down the line if a flanking unit was approaching. If you get caught trying to make your way through some thick brush, you're probably dead.

>>178284767
>Yes there’s was horrendous battles during WW1 Western Front, but when we look at the day to day life it was in fact far more easier compared to say the WW2 Eastern Front.
Bullshit. Shell-shock is a form of PTSD almost exclusive to WW1 because of how psychologically fucked up it was to sit in a trench and be shot at by artillery for hours. Yes, you'd spend days and weeks bored in the trenches. And every now and then one of your buddies lets the boredom get the better of him and has his head blown off in front of you because a sniper caught a glimpse of him. When it rains, your trench turns into a disease-riddled swamp. If you don't get tuberculosis, you're still guaranteed to get trench foot and you better hope you'll get switched out from front service soon so your foot doesn't just rot away. When you try to sleep, rats will nibble away at any exposed body part. Or some enemy trench raider managed to sneak in and murders you in your sleep. And then there are your retarded officers who will randomly tell you to charge through machine gun fire at the enemy trench. If you survive that, you can listen to the cacophony of groaning of your dying comrades for hours because no one can get them out of the death strip. It's precisely the mix of boredom and abrupt hell that drove people nuts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178285635
>my artillery pins you down as my overwhelming infantry force storms your trench
That's unironically the right answer. Castles fell out of military use because artillery became too powerful, building an O or U shaped mud wall behind a trench is just asking to get blasted by artillery while your infantry stays out of musket range. Once there is only a trench left, you charge as a narrow line at the trenches. The whole deal with early fire weapons is that they take long to reload, are imprecise and prone to misfire. The whole line formation thing is about concentrating fire and negating those things. If your men are spread out in a U shape in a narrow trench, they can't concentrate fire and will barely be able to pick off the enemy who is charging at them from one direction. Use cavalry to kill off any stragglers, because the enemy cavalry is necessarily dead from being a huge target that didn't fit in the trenches and got blown away behind the mud wall.

I'm a trans individual who has been on /tv/ for years. I've yet to see any definitive proof that anything which is largely accepted by the trans community is bad for them, and I'm here to address these issues.

Let's get a hot topic out of the way first: gender reassignment surgery is as necessary for individuals experiencing severe gender dysphoria as chemo would be for a cancer patient. Yes, some people still unfortunately kill themselves. But, every single person who undergoes surgery who doesnt is a person whose life is saved. It is not cosmetic, it is life saving.

Secondly, estrogen is not bad for your mind or body in any way as an assigned-at-birth male. There is zero scientific evidence that it is. This is baseless and only serves to scare people away from taking the medicine they need

Third: it can be "too late to change". I am 37 and I only began hrt 5 years ago. Within two years I was visually passing and now my voice sounds indistinguishable from any other woman's.

Finally, that it is bad for children to transition. Most children have no issue with this and think it's cool to know a trans individual. And giving children estrogen does in fact make it easier on them psychologically to go through their lives as a woman. There is zero evidence that any child has experienced adverse effects growing up compared to non-trans children.

I will talk to anyone about any of these things. I'm just sick of seeing baseless bullshit spewed about us on this board. Seeing that stuff early on in my transition made me think about some things I never want to think about again. And anyone who posts pictures of girls who are having trouble passing is participating in psychological abuse.

>The Star Wars films by George Lucas have made some serious attempts to illustrate a planet like Trantor, the first being Coruscant (which was in some early sources called "Jhantor", in homage to Trantor). Coruscant is one of the more convincing images on screen we have today of Isaac Asimov's conception of the world-girdling city of Trantor. Coruscant is a planet-covering open-air city, while Trantor's buildings are all subterranean or under domes due to worsening weather conditions. Asimov's Trantor thus differs from Coruscant in that Trantor is more practically adapted to inclement weather, although weather control devices are used on both planets. It should be noted that there is a planet called Trantor in the Star Wars universe, and it is also an ecumenopolis.

Did anyone else realize that Cameron used his experience in documentaries to make these movies look more real?
Like in the first one there's a scene where they're flying on those bird animals and there's a shot with a zoom with a shaky cam and that's not the kind of zoom you use in a movie that tries to be immersive but it's done to make your mind think that this stuff is real and it's being recorded like a documentary

>>178285122
Avatar 1 is much better. All though not a very original story it is very well told. It has good pacing a great bad guy and a good face off at the end. On top of that the world itself was stunningly made.

Avatar 2 on the other hand did not have a well written story. Or even particularly original at that. Resurrecting two dead characters from movie 1 is an absolute no go for me. The casual mention of the reason of the return of the humans was a bit to easy. After the tullies left forest town i presume the war with the humans continued? Part 2 is basically planet earth. The (over)usage of the words bro and cous' weren't my cup of tea either. Part 3 of the film is an horrendous mess. Its like free willy into avatar 1 and titanic made into one movie. Kids get captured, escape, get captured again, leave the ship, get on the ship again. That was just shite. The standoff with Quaritsj was good but basically avatar 1. So Cameron probably didn't want to end it like this so he turned into the

Wanted to like it but i simply cannot. For a movie that was 13 years in the making you think he could have written something better with less pacing problems. Visually it looks very good, i have no problem with that at all. I don't think the humans should have returned at all or even be made the bad guys again. I would have preferred a story about some kind of struggle with one of the many tribes on Pandora. We could have explored new tribes on new adventures without rehashing all the old stuff and the classic humans are bad stuff.

Anyways those are just my 2 cents. Peace uut!

>Home Alone was initially set to be financed and distributed by Warner Bros. Hughes promised that he could make the movie for less than $10 million, considerably less than most feature film production budgets of that era. Concerned that the film might exceed that amount, Hughes met secretly with 20th Century Fox before production to see if they would fund the project if Warner proved inflexible. According to executive producer Scott Rosenfelt, a copy of the script was "clandestinely" delivered to Fox, bypassing the legal restrictions that would have otherwise prevented Fox from seeing it until the project was in turnaround.[16] Early in production, the budget grew to $14.7 million. Warner demanded that it be cut by $1.2 million; the producers responded with a memo arguing that the budget could not be cut any further. "The two came out, bowed formally and then began to fight. Wong adopted a classic stance whereas Bruce, who at the time was still using his Wing Chun style, produced a series of straight punches. Within a minute, Wong's men were trying to stop the fight as Bruce began to warm to his task. James Lee warned them to let the fight continue. A minute later, with Bruce continuing the attack in earnest, Wong began to backpedal as fast as he could. For an instant, indeed, the scrap threatened to degenerate into a farce as Wong actually turned and ran. But Bruce pounced on him like a springing leopard and brought him to the floor where he began pounding him into a state of demoralization. "Is that enough?" shouted Bruce, "That's enough!" pleaded his adversary. Bruce demanded a second reply to his question to make sure that he understood this was the end of the fight."

In Bruce Lee: A Life by Matthew Polly, who shares a few insights from his extensive research and interview process, he says that according to David Chin, who arranged the match on Wong's behalf, Lee overwhelmed Wong with his opening series of attacks as Wong was approaching for the customary salute, causing Wong to turn his back and run. Lee chased him around the room until Wong tripped and fell. Lee jumped on top of Wong and rained down punches, forcing Chin to intervene and rescue Wong.

Lee gave a description, without naming Wong explicitly, in an interview with Black Belt.

"I'd gotten into a fight in San Francisco with a Kung-Fu cat, and after a brief encounter the son-of-a-bitch started to run. I chased him and, like a fool, kept punching him behind his head and back. Soon my fists began to swell from hitting his hard head. Right then I realized Wing Chun was not too practical and began to alter my way of fighting."

>>178272067
He and his boys would get into scraps during their Hong Kong Opera School days. Jackie is a gang-fighter. Lee was known (or mythologized) as a one-to-one guy in early hometown fights (against other tiny, underfed asian dudes). Jackie and co were all well-fed because the Opera School was well funded and they drilled stage-acrobatics and dance all day. They were coordinated and other street scrappers were gang fighters too.

Samo Hung was apparently a real mean bastard in street fights and used his ballooning weight to his advantage. Jackie was always considered "big" among his peers too. He was called Pou Pou or something like that, meaning "cannon ball" because his head was so big and solid (also his dad was a chef in an embassy, so he was getting lots of food from day one). Look at his other buddies Yuen Biao and Yuen Wah, they were considered tiny and skinny, and they map closest to Bruce Lee in terms of acrobatic speed and flexibility on screen (particularly in the Green Hornet where he moves a million miles an hour - very similar to Biao and Wah in the earlier movies). It was in his later movies that Lee tried to push into the new "coiled spring" figure with a boosted muscle load.

As filmmakers, I'd say they're on par with each other. But each mastered a different sub-genre of martial arts movies. Jackie is the better stuntman (obviously), but Lee had the superior story-sense of how a fight should unfold. That holding back is just as important as that final wild energy. You can see Jackie attempting these Lee moments when he had a guy like Benny Urquidez to work with, but it would still spiral into those amazing acrobatic moves. And it was better for him to follow that road than keep living in Lee's (screen) shadow. He was a master of marshaling chaos on screen, while Lee was a master of stripping things down to bare essentials.

It is a myth that Jackie Chan does all of his stunts. He has used stunt doubles for various things going back to his kung fu days (stuff like an acrobatic flip for one shot that he couldn't do as well as one of his friends). And even some of the big stuff, like the clock tower fall in Project A, the evidence suggests that at least one of the long shot takes was Mars not Jackie. And I'm not taking anything away from Jackie, he has done a ton of insane stunts and gotten real injuries and has made great fight scenes and all that stuff. I own several of his films. But the "he never uses a stuntman!" thing was largely American promotional talk.

Its harder to hit a smaller target which explains why Aegon survived despite being the only target. Jace was also engaged in a prolonged battle where he would've been making repetitive loops within shooting range. Aegon left in a singular direction away from the ships and was within the range of fire for a much shorter period of time. We're talking less than a minute vs 30 minutes, possibly over an hour.
>Daeron
There are 3 accounts to how he died, two of which state he died at the hand of an enemy combatant and the other being that he died in a burning tent. You should acknowledge he and his troops were taken by surprise with dragon fire being used. All three known possible causes of deaths make sense.
Its perfectly fine to say you dislike the cause and timings of the deaths. Jacerys and Daeron were both young and rising leaders who were off the backs of major successes leaving them inches away from victory. They potentially could've had greater arcs but people make choices and George chose this version of events which would've gone very differently if Jacerys or Daeron didn't die at that time.

“It has always been so. I am not . . . I am not a cruel man, Ser Davos. You know me. Have known me long. This is not my decree. It has always been so, since Aegon’s day and before. >As I have mentioned in half a hundred interviews over the years, when I am doing my worldbuilding, I often start with some real world event or location, and “turn it up to 11.” That’s a SPINAL TAP reference, of course, and maybe not precise. In some cases I turn it up to 111, or 11,000. The Wall, for instance. Inspired by my visit to Hadrian’s Wall, but three times as long and way way taller, made of ice and magic.

>The origins of Casterly Rock are somewhat similar. This time my inspiration was the Rock of Gibraltar.

>A depressing number of people only seem to know Gibraltar as the trademark for Prudential Insurance.

>I grew up with that image myself. But believe it or not, the Rock of Gibraltar is not just a stony version of the Geico Gekko. It is a real place, a unique place, with thousands of years of history. To the ancients it was one of the Pillars of Hercules (the other pillar is far less impressive), the gateway between the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic. Today it is a British outpost at the bottom of Spain, one of the last remnants of an empire that once spanned the globe. I visited there some years ago, on one of my tours through Spain and Portugal, and found the place just as fascinating in person as I had in print. It’s the home of the Barbary apes, who will hop on your back and steal your hat and eyeglasses if you let them. There are British pubs and fish-and-chip shops all over the town at the Rock’s foot, as well as some amazing Spanish restaurants. And INSIDE the Rock… it’s not just a big hunk of stone, y’see… are 34 miles of tunnels, more than 150 halls, chambers, and caves, Napoleonic gunports and cannons looking out over land and sea, stalagmites and stalactites, World War II bunkers, a concert hall/ ampitheatre, a hospital (WWII era), and ancient mines.

posts.sub: Max Shreck is the best Batman villain in the movies
posts.com:
I recently saw Batman Returns at the cinema and realized this is the best Batman villain out of all his films and that Returns is the best Batman movie.
First of all watching old movies at the cinema made me realize that you're really supposed to watch them there and it's basically a different medium from watching them at your home.
Masterpieces are 100x times better and a movie like Batman Returns which I considered mediocre or good at best makes a lot more sense when you watch it on the big screen on actual film.
This made me realize how great Returns is compared to all the other ones, and that Max Shreck is the best villain in a Batman movie so far.
He's bad, he makes sense, but most importantly he's fun to watch in every scene and he's hilarious. He's kind of like J Jonah Jameson the way he lacks self awareness and acts completely selfish. When he finds out Catwoman is Selina and instantly says "You're fired" you really understand the genius of this character, same when he asks Bruce why he's dressed as the Batman.
He's one of those characters that make every scene fun to watch.
If you don't understand that he's the best Batman villain out of all the films you're basically gay and retarded.
I used to talk a lot of shit about Burton's Batman and at best considered his movies watchable and mostly good for the aesthetics but I have to say Batman Returns is really good and aged very well.
I think it might even be the best comic book movie ever despite not being faithful or as exciting as movies that came after.

First, the Joker doesn't make sense in universe. He only makes sense as a meta character. He knows what everyone will do cause everyone is a character in a movie and he knows the script. He can't possibly know what everyone will do in universe and the movie is made in a way that implies it's supposed to be realistic. So the Joker being a meta character that knows what everyone does cause he knows it's a movie doesn't make sense, it's cool, but doesn't make sense.
Almost none of the things he plan make sense in a semi-realistic movie like this. And it's a joke that he just enters the place where all the biggest Gotham bosses meet up and no one just shoots him as soon as he shows up. There's this contrast between cartoon logic and realistic logic, and it's not even gritty realism like it wants to be, none of the criminals here are bad, they're just tv show criminals.

Also, Dent isn't half Batman half Joker, there's no Batman in him, he's just straight up evil by the end of the movie.

The movie only makes sense if you think it's a Michael Bay movie. It doesn't work as a comic book movie, doesn't work as a realistic crime thriller, it only works as a Michael Bay type american blockbuster, and in that way it is kinda good, it's like an average american movie with american values where there's a villain that breaks the fourth wall cause he's like Jack Sparrow if he came out of a Saw type movie. Harvey Dent in Court acting like an american hero is the trope of a phony hero from an american tv show, Batman is this guy that just buys big toys and destroys everything to bring justice, and the Joker is some meta character that just plays around with a movie that's the wrong genre.
This is the trick of the movie and it's pretty gay once you see through it, still kinda cool when you watch the Joker scenes, but once you get it it's a pain to go through the rest of the movie.

I’m fascinated by beds. Beds can tell you a lot about the person who sleeps in them. The looks, the materials, the (lack of) softness. The amount of pillows.
I have a particular interest in femcel beds. Pic related belongs to a femcel in her early 30s, I think. There are a few things of note here. First of all, there’s some effort at display here. Everything is color coordinated and she said she made the sunflower blanket herself. This is clearly someone who cares about aesthetics, yet it is also clearly someone who isn’t very cool — it’s a very dorky bed. Obviously, it’s also kind of a tiny bed, and the frame looks very childish. Not a bed you can invite a man into. Has she given up? Does she just expect to stay single forever? Does she not like being in a big bed? Does she just have no clue about seduction and relationships?
>b-but you can get close to each other in a tiny bed!
Yeah so there’s a reason no actual couples sleep like this if they don’t have to.
Now, the other mattress below the bed is really mysterious. It’s clearly for a single bed too. Does she ever do that hotel thing where she puts two single beds together? Does she put it on the floor if a femcel friend comes over for a sleepover. Does she have bigger blankets somewhere? Why does someone who clearly cares about aesthetics keep that ugly mattress there? Does the ugly plastic bag not bother her? Has she ever even taken it out?

>After a huge opening weekend and now sitting atop $661 million in global receipts after its first week of release, James Cameron’s eagerly anticipated sequel to the chart-topping 2009 sci-fi blockbuster Avatar is expected to see lower-than hoped for domestic receipts due to extreme conditions across much of the USA through the holiday weekend. People won’t venture out as much as blizzards and icy conditions make travel hazardous, and power outages force many to huddle at home without heat
>But global conditions don’t mirror those stateside, and Avatar 2 is still racking up massive daily tallies as it heads into its second weekend. International sales should be strong enough to boost total worldwide numbers toward $200+ million, although continued uncontrolled spread of Covid across China threatens to suppress turnout there again and could pull final weekend figures down to the $190+/- million territory. That’s still good enough for an $850 million cume by end of weekend business, and anything north of $190-200 million would lift the film closer toward $900 million.
>900 million in a week

To me the best part about this movie was realizing it's not just Avatar but Cameron deciding this was going to be his magnum opus and basically doing a Lord of the Rings with stuff from all of his movies
Like you see pictures of Chrome Lords (AI generated fake movie screenshots) and you think wow this is what people in the 90s dreamed movies would be like in the 2010s. Like you watch Terminator 2 in the 90s and think damn can't wat for 2015 to have an epic movie with an army of Terminators and instead you have Terminator Salvation and it's some kind of Transformers garbage. We never had those movies.
Then I realized than Cameron was preparing those movies and worked decades to make them a reality and you watch Avatar 2 and you have the scene from Terminator with the atomic bomb going off and destroying everything and armies of robots dropping from an airship and you just get it.
It's not just about the blue niggas it's about everything Cameron likes in one movie.
I mean you can say that this is some tree hugging bullshit about natives but you can tell Cameron loves the hi-tech military stuff just as much. He's not just doing a movie about an alien world he's trying to make a trilogy that explores every cool thing possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178283227
I'm the same. I remember enjoying the first film in cinemas but purely only for the effects/technology and the fact I was an easily impressed teenager. Rewatching it afterwards left me very turned off from further movies. But I watched TWOW just cause nothing else was on and I really did not expect to be THAT impressed by the CGI and overall production quality. I think this film is even further ahead in terms of spectacle and special effects compared to other 2022 films, than the first film was compared to other films from 2009. And after over a decade of near constant soulless regurgitated slop by Marvel that feels like it gets uglier and less creative as years go by, Avatar 2 is just a genuinely well made classic blockbuster with as much attention as possible paid to making a spectacle that wows with every shot. While the story is very basic, I even found myself enjoying the characters and liking things like the fact there is a respectable and caring father figure portrayed on film, or a simple yet effective coming of age story for a group of likable new young characters. I think I will watch it again so I can see if 3D makes a difference, but really even in 2D I am happy to have a film that is genuinely worth going to the cinema for, the only one this year after Top Gun Maverick.

I'm the same. I remember enjoying the first film in cinemas but purely only for the effects/technology and the fact I was an easily impressed teenager. Rewatching it afterwards left me very turned off from further movies. But I watched TWOW just cause nothing else was on and I really did not expect to be THAT impressed by the CGI and overall production quality. I think this film is even further ahead in terms of spectacle and special effects compared to other 2022 films, than the first film was compared to other films from 2009. And after over a decade of near constant soulless regurgitated slop by Marvel that feels like it gets uglier and less creative as years go by, Avatar 2 is just a genuinely well made classic blockbuster with as much attention as possible paid to making a spectacle that wows with every shot. While the story is very basic, I even found myself enjoying the characters and liking things like the fact there is a respectable and caring father figure portrayed on film, or a simple yet effective coming of age story for a group of likable new young characters. I think I will watch it again so I can see if 3D makes a difference, but really even in 2D I am happy to have a film that is genuinely worth going to the cinema for, the only one this year after Top Gun Maverick.

I have a heavy suspicion that Corvette Summer was made to screen-test his rebuilt face, and run a comparison with his near-lookalike from Laserblast. If the skin-grafts and nose reconstruction (and muscle repair?) hadn't taken so well, I think the other guy would have been brought in as Replacement Luke.

The different lighting at times in the movie shows where the damage is accumulated, as the skin-grafts reflect light differently to the normal skin, and his right upper lip is still not functioning at 100%. Basically proving the original "rumor" correct, that his whole nose got ripped off and the inner right cheek and side of mouth/teeth got wrecked too. The movie puts him through his emotional and performance paces seemingly to test him for any major limitations.

Worth noting that Annie Potts was also recovering from a serious car accident injury too, except it was her back and she was barely back up and walking without aid when they started filming (which you can see at times in the movie that she's till getting her stride smoothed out). Was Potts a replacement Leia candidate too? (since Carrie could OD at any moment)

Star Wars was the biggest wave cresting in Hollywood in years, so it's not unreasonable to think that this quick cheap movie may have been an emergency "continuity check" on the biggest new hero of cinema at the time. Also, the filmmakers went on to do Dragonslayer which was a very expensive golden-ticket sort of project for two such young inexperienced guys. Favor repaid perhaps (even though it was Disney)?
